column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My 9 year old daughter was prescribed Ciprodex and completed the 1 week dosage period with no relief from her ear pain said to be from an irritated ear canal/infection.  It was expensive and it doesn't seem to help very many people based on the reviews.  I wish I would have known that and I will not except another prescription for this medication.  Our first experience with ear drops and it failed.  Now I need to make another appointment, pay for another office visit pay for another prescription and waste a beautiful afternoon with my children while we all sit at the doctors office!

column2: 4Eyes, 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: I saw an ear doctor today to flush out my ears which were clogged. A doctor's aide did the procedure. The next thing I knew, the doctor had given orders that I buy and use ciprodex otic although he never saw me after my ears were flushed, I had no symptoms of an ear infection and he never explained the reason for his diagnosis or possible side effects. Of course, there was the famous "coupon" for paying $20 instead of $144. It seems that this is another crooked partnership of doctors with pharmaceutical companies. With an office full of Medicaid/Medicare, one might even suspect that kickbacks are involved. Another disappointing encounter with American medical care - the best in the world! (if you're a doctor or drug company)

column2: socal, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Used Ciprodex in conjunction with oral antibiotic Ciprofloxacin for outer ear infection.  The good, no real side effects experienced and infection seems to have cleared up.  The bad, after Ciprodex treatment (3 drops x 6 days twice a day) my hearing has not improved (not any worse just has not gotten any better), this comment comes three days after stopping ear drops. My ENT Doctor thinks I could have fluid build up behind my eardrum causing my hearing not to improve.  Has ordered hearing test and follow-up in two weeks to see if my hearing has improved.  If not, wants me to think about putting hole in ear tube to drain fluid.  However, 1% to 3% chance of permanent hearing loss. Still on Ciprofloxacin for another two days.

column1: Other
column2: Sean, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was prescribed this by a doctor for chronic itchy ear canals (likely due to irritation by overuse of q-tips). Was given 5 refills and told to go on and off as needed. I asked the doctor to go with something without an antibiotic as an infection wasn't really my problem, he disregarded this and had no concerns. Took the first prescription and had no issues, itchy ears cleared up. Slowly the itching came back so took the second round of it. Upon completion of this I experienced noticeable hearing loss and tinnitus in my left ear. Followed up with doctors and it appears this is permanent and a result of ototoxicity. Ciprodex was not as safe was was indicated and the over-prescription by the doctor likely contributed to the problem. The itchy ear canals came back after treatment anyways so in any event it would have been a poor option even if it didn't create much more serious problems.

column2: AnnaNicole, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have an inner/outer ear infection and my doctor prescribed Ciprodex and Amoxicillan.  After only 1 use of Ciprodex, I experienced total hearing loss in both ears. It has now been 2 weeks and although the hearing loss has improved somewhat, I still have significant hearing loss, especially my right ear.  My ENT doctor says I should consider a hearing aid as a result of this horrible side effect!  I am curious if this has occurred to anyone else and what their experience has been.  I just want my hearing back!  I am contacting the FDA right away!

column1: Other
column2: frandee, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have a long-time perforated eardrum, and got a middle-ear infection after a cold. My doctor prescrined these drops. My first reaction was to the price - very expensive! After a few days of inserting the drops, my palms and fingers started itching and I developed a rash. Read the medicine insert, which listed a rash as a possible negative side effect. The doctor was adament that no connection - that rash from the drops would be local, i.e. at or around the ear. I was almost at end of my 10-day course of drops, so continued for 3 more days. Once I stopped the drops, the rash and itching stopped. But now the skin on my hands has been peeling off. Very dry, scratchy and uncomfortable. Could this be a result of the drops? PS - My ear infection's better tho!
